online.game
Class commonCanvas

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Canvas
          online.common.exCanvas
              online.game.commonCanvas
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.Observer, javax.accessibility.Accessible, CanvasProtocol, deferredEventHandler, OnlineConstants, Play2Constants, sgf_names, ViewerProtocol, ViewGameProtocol
Direct Known Subclasses:
CheckerGameViewer, HexGameViewer
public abstract class commonCanvas
extends exCanvas
implements ViewerProtocol, CanvasProtocol, sgf_names

This class extends exCanvas and provides a bunch of services for the individual game's Viewer class. Many of the requirements of ViewerProtocol are implemented here, and will not needs to be done by the game's subclass.
The main services are

  • a history of moves in the game
  • a "VCR cluster" of forward-back controls to view the game history.
  • mouse handling
  • repaint management
  • some standard option menus
  • debugging aids for screen layout and performance
  • a run loop

    See Also:
    exCanvas, Serialized Form

    reviewOnly

    public boolean reviewOnly
    normally, the game record is considered immutable during a game, but becomes mutable by the players after the game is over. What starts as a regular game is never mutable by spectators. What starts as a game review is mutable by everyone.

    MoveStep

    public int MoveStep()

    Digest

    public long Digest()
    this provides the game state, digested as a unique integer, for the game controller for fraud detection (the fraud being to play the same game over and over to inflate your score). It's used at midgame as well as endgame, to uniquely identify this game.

    Specified by:

    setControlToken

    public void setControlToken(boolean val,
                            long timeStamp)
    set ownership of the control token, with the timestamp if it's pending false,0 means we are relinquishing control false,nnn means we have requested control true,nnn means we have received acknowlegement of our claim of control if nnn isn't the same as controlToken, then there is a control fight going on and we shouldn't claim control even if the val is true

    Specified by:
    setControlToken in interface ViewGameProtocol

    currenRobotPlayer

    public commonPlayer currenRobotPlayer()

    doMouseTracking

    public void doMouseTracking(commonPlayer player,
                            java.lang.String zone,
                            int inx,
                            int iny,
                            int ino)
    Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
    Record the latest mouse tracking information about the player (or spectator). only remembering, no other action, should occur. By convention, record nothing if player happens to be self. Also by convention, if inx is >=0 it reflects an object begin moved by the player, and all the other players should be set to not be moving. By convention, there is at most one moving object in the game at any time.

    Specified by:
    doMouseTracking in interface ViewGameProtocol
    Parameters:
    player - the player, or spectator.
    zone - default "on" "board" or "off", or whatever means something to your viewer
    inx - encoded x coordinate
    iny - encoded y coordinate
    ino - if >=0 represents an object being moved.

    Specified by:
    setLimbo in interface ViewGameProtocol

    UndoStep

    public void UndoStep()
    move the view of the game history back one step. The default inplementation does this the simplest and dumbest way, by calling "doWayBack()" and then stepping forward. For most circumstances this should be fine. You can override this method with a fancier or smarter UNDO if needed.

    doWayBack

    public void doWayBack()
    move the view of the game history all the way back to the beginning. This could be implemented cleverly, but the simple and reliable method is to just reinialize the board.

    PerformAndTransmit

    public boolean PerformAndTransmit(commonMove m,
                                  boolean transmit,
                                  replayMode mode)
    perform and optionally transmit a move, return true if ok. Note, it's tempting to do any "auto move" that is needed in the continuation of this method, but don't. Doing so may separate the "perform" from the "transmit" which will lead to other players seeing the events out of order. Instead, use the continuation of ViewerRun

    Parameters:
    m -
    transmit -
    mode - replay mode
    Returns:
    true if successful

    EditHistory

    public commonMove EditHistory(commonMove m)
    the contract of editHistory is to remove unnecessary elements from the game history, resulting in a tidy record that when replayed, results in a duplicate of the current state. This default method works by taking a game digest after every move, and assuming that if the game digest reverts to a previous value, it must be an undo back to that move. Scanning back stops with a MOVE_DONE

    Parameters:
    m -
    Returns:
    a move to be added to the history, or null

                              boolean okSame)

    popHistoryElement

    public commonMove popHistoryElement()
    call this from your EditHistory(online.game.commonMove) method to remove a superfluous element at idx. Note that this maintains both the move tree in the commonMove elements, and the History list which contains the current linear path to the current move in the tree. Usually idx is the current last move in the history, and usually it has no successors. This method works to remove elements that are not leaves of the tree, but that is not usually something you want to do. Routine use by EditHistory should always remove leaves.

    popHistoryElement

    public commonMove popHistoryElement(int idx)

    AddToHistory

    public boolean AddToHistory(commonMove originalnewmove)
    add to the history, but also edit the current move in progress so we don't clutter the history with extra steps. This doesn't hurt anything, but it looks bad and makes the move slider slide. At the point we get there, the move has already been fully performed, so only the history vector itself is affected.

    Returns:
    true if the current move was added to history

    doInit

    public void doInit(boolean preserve_history)
    Description copied from interface: ViewerProtocol
    initialize back to the "start" position. This is used when a reviewer is about to load a new game, or when the "WayBack" button is pressed. In particular, this implies that the players list (and maybe also the game subtype) may change. As invoked by the game controller, "preserve_history" will always be false, indicating that history should be discarded.

    printGameRecord

    public void printGameRecord(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                            java.lang.String startingTime,
                            OStack<commonMove> his)
    print the game record directly from the history. This is the way games are recorded by the server: printed by this printwriter into a string, which is transmitted to the server over the net connection, and the server writes the file. The net effect should be very similar to the SGF output.

    ViewerRun

    public void ViewerRun()
    Description copied from class: exCanvas
    this is the run loop for the window. All significant events should occur here. Actions due to network, mouse, or keyboard should be deferred and handled here. Canvas painting is also deferred and handles here.

    About the only thing that doesn't happen here is activity by robots to search for next moves.

    Specified by:
    ViewerRun in interface CanvasProtocol
    Overrides:
    ViewerRun in class exCanvas
    See Also:

    performHistoryInitialization

    public abstract void performHistoryInitialization(java.util.StringTokenizer his)

    simultaneous_turns_allowed

    public boolean simultaneous_turns_allowed(commonPlayer whoseTurn)
    return true if simultaneous game actions are allowed right now. In most games with synchronous moves, this is always false. In games with simultaneous actions like Raj, it is sometimes true. The effect of "true" is that communications with the server are held to a baseline and the players are allowed to overwrite each other's view of the most recent move.

    Specified by:
    simultaneous_turns_allowed in interface ViewGameProtocol
    Parameters:
    whoseTurn -
    Returns:
    true if simultaneous game actions are allowed right now

    useStoryBuffer

    public void useStoryBuffer(java.lang.String tok,
                           java.util.StringTokenizer his)
    Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
    interpret a history string as created by formHistoryString. The contract is to bring the local game into the same state as the game that created the string. This is used to give spectators the view of the game, and also to reconnect players that have been disconnected.

    Specified by:
    useStoryBuffer in interface ViewGameProtocol

    verifyGameRecord

    public void verifyGameRecord()
    verify the game record is still correct by cloning the board and replaying it. This is intended to catch "editing errors" by editHistory, but may also catch cases where Digest() is not producing the same result. In the process this exercises a lot of the game machinery, so other latent bugs are likely to show up right away as errors thrown from verifyGameRecord
    To assist with certain phases of debugging, where all this replaying can be confusing, set DISABLE_VERIFY=true;
